channel.title: The comic arts
channel.description:
A series devoted to humor, humorists, and comedy writing in America.

An online collection of early educational public radio content from the National Association of Educational Broadcasters (NAEB).

item.title: Program 6 of 13
item.description: Jack E. Leonard, Eloise Martin, Robert Orben, and Earl Wilson discuss the importance of having good comedy writers who work behind the scenes to supply good material.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Writing

item.title: Program 8 of 13
item.description: Television today is the ultimate comic medium. This great electronic conveyor commands public attention every hour of the day, reaches every corner of the land, and is part and parcel of our way of life. George Q. Lewis, Danny Thomas, Chuck McCann, Jack E. Leonard, and Marcel Marceau discuss television as a medium of both challenge and frustration for the working comic or writer.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Writing

item.title: Program 13 of 13
item.description: Art Buchwald, Earl Wilson, David McCord, and H. Allen Smith discuss the current relative scarcity of humor columnists and humorous books.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Writing

item.title: Program 11 of 13
item.description: Art Buchwald, H. Allen Smith, and David McCord discuss the evolution of the American sense of humor and the current climate for humorous writing.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Writing

item.title: Program 2 of 13
item.description: H. Allen Smith, Robert Orben, Chuck McCann, Joan Rivers share their definitions of what constitutes a sense of humor.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Wit and humor

item.title: Program 5 of 13
item.description: Harold Lloyd, Eloise Martin, Sam Levinson, Chuck McCann, and Henny Youngman describe the persistence, experimentation, and intestinal fortitude needed to become a professional comic.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Wit and humor

item.title: Program 12 of 13
item.description: The life of the humorous author is an adventure combining the principal features of hunting for a needle in a haystack with those of a wild goose chase. H. Allen Smith and Art Buchwald share their experiences in publishing humorous books, and Sam Levinson shares his views on the importance of humor to our society, our culture, and our life.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Writing--Psychological aspects

item.title: Program 1 of 13
item.description: Comedians Sam Levinson, George Q. Lewis, Danny Thomas, and Robert Orban offer their appraisal of the American sense of humor and how it has evolved during difficult times.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Wit and humor

item.title: Program 9 of 13
item.description: Harold Lloyd discusses his role in silent film comedy. Chuck McCann and Danny Thomas describe how they were influenced by comedy in films.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Wit and humor

item.title: Program 10 of 13
item.description: Jack E. Leonard, Earl Wilson, Henny Youngman, Joan Rivers, and Danny Thomas share their experiences working the nightclub circuit.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Wit and humor

item.title: Program 3 of 13
item.description: Sam Levinson, Harold Lloyd, Joan Rivers, and Henny Youngman describe their introduction to the world of comedy as well as the nature of the comedic gift.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Wit and humor

item.title: Program 7 of 13
item.description: Jo Anne Worley, Earl Wilson, George Q. Lewis, H. Allen Smith, and Sam Levinson discuss their perceptions of and involvement with stage productions.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Wit and humor

item.title: Program 4 of 13
item.description: Danny Thomas, Eloise Martin, Chuck McCann, Paul Ashby, Bill McGuire, and Edward Everett Horton offer their wisdom on venues where beginning comics can practice and be bad before hitting the big time.
item.dc:creator: Michigan State University
item.dc:subject: Wit and humor
